data.wave_or_subset: 2003 PISA; analysis of 15-year-old students across 41 countries; used five plausible values for mathematics achievement
data.unit_of_analysis: Individual students nested within schools (and schools within countries); multilevel structure
data.notes: Single-wave (cross-sectional) data; used plausible values for achievement (five plausible values) and sample weights as recommended by PISA; many psychological constructs measured on 4-point Likert scales with reported Cronbach's alphas; analyses aggregated/preserved constructs in a common metric for comparability; limitations noted due to single wave (no causal inference).

method.description: Cross-sectional multilevel (hierarchical) modeling of PISA 2003 data to examine the Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect (BFLPE) on mathematics self-concept and to test moderation by 16 individual/student constructs (e.g., SES indicators, motivation, self-efficacy, learning strategies, anxiety, social orientations). Students nested within schools and schools within countries; analyses used plausible values for math achievement and sample weights; each moderator examined via interaction with school-average ability using multilevel regressions and results averaged across plausible values.
method.steps: 1) Obtain 2003 PISA data and select relevant sample (15-year-old students across participating countries). 2) Compute student-level constructs/scales (e.g., math self-concept, intrinsic/extrinsic motivation, self-efficacy, anxiety, learning strategies, SES indicators) using items on 4-point Likert scales and report reliability (Cronbach's alpha). 3) Compute individual math ability using plausible values (five plausible values) and compute school-average math ability. 4) Standardize/preserve constructs in a common metric for comparability. 5) For each moderator, run multilevel regression models (students within schools within countries) including individual ability (linear and quadratic), school-average ability, the moderator, and the interaction between moderator and school-average ability. 6) Perform these regressions separately for each of the five plausible values. 7) Average estimates across plausible values to produce final parameter estimates. 8) Compute effect sizes for interactions using a formula comparable to Cohen's d and prioritize substantive (practically meaningful) effects over mere statistical significance. 9) Use recommended PISA sample weights in analyses and adopt a stringent significance threshold (p < .001).
method.models: Multilevel (hierarchical) linear models (three-level structure: students within schools within countries). Interaction models between school-average ability and individual-level moderators. Separate models run per plausible value and averaged across plausible values.
method.independent_variables: Primary predictors: school-average mathematics ability (contextual predictor), individual mathematics ability (plausible values; linear and quadratic terms), moderators including intrinsic motivation, extrinsic/instrumental motivation, math self-efficacy, math anxiety, learning strategies (elaboration, memorization, control strategies), cooperative orientation, competitive orientation, sense of belonging, student-teacher relations, SES indicators (parental education, home educational resources, cultural possessions), and other measured constructs.
method.control_variables: Model includes individual-level ability (linear and quadratic), school- and country-level random effects (three-level modeling), use of sample weights; other specific covariates beyond those explicitly reported are not specified in the provided summary.

results.summary: The study confirmed a robust Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect (BFLPE): higher school-average ability is associated with lower individual mathematics self-concept while individual ability positively predicts self-concept. The BFLPE generalized across SES and many self-regulation constructs. Some moderators showed small but substantive moderation: positive student-teacher relations and sense of belonging reduced the negative impact of school-average ability on math self-concept. Anxiety and reliance on memorization amplified the negative BFLPE. Intrinsic and extrinsic motivation and self-efficacy positively predicted math self-concept but generally did not meaningfully attenuate the BFLPE. SES interactions with school-average ability were generally negligible. Due to the large sample, many interactions reached statistical significance, but effect sizes were often small; the authors emphasized substantive effect sizes over mere statistical significance.

numerical_results.effect_size: reported as moderating (reduced negative impact) but numeric effect size not stated
numerical_results.p_value: some interactions reported as significant at p<.001
